In this section, we introduce the background knowledge of deep learning, cross-silo federated learning, homomorphic encryption, ring learning with errors problem, and CKKSâ€™s encoding method.
TableÂ I summarizes mathematical notations used in this paper.

S8.T2.caption: TABLE II: Network bandwidth between the server and the clients in different regions.
S8.T2.table:
Region HK LDN TYO. N. VA. Ore.
Uplink (Mbps) 81 97 116 165 9841
Downlink (Mbps) 84 84 122 151 9841
references:
We consider the same geo-distributed FL scenario as BatchCrypt, where the clients train an ML model in five AWS EC2 datacenters located in Hong Kong, London, Tokyo, N. Virginia, and Oregon, and the aggregator is run in the Oregon datacenter.
The network bandwidth between the aggregator and the clients is presented in TableÂ II.
We employ synchronous stochastic gradient descent method to train all the ML models.

Training to Convergence.
We next compare the total training time and network traffic of FATE, BatchCrypt, and ESAFL until they are trained to convergence.
Because the whole training process requires exceedingly high costs in both time and traffic, we simulate distributed training of FL locally until the model converges, and estimate the total time and communication cost needed for convergence according to the network bandwidth in TableÂ II and the number of iterations in the local training.
TableÂ V presents the estimation results of FATE, BatchCrypt, ESAFL, and plain FL.
Compared with FATE and BatchCrypt, ESAFL lowers both training time and network traffic required for convergence.
Specifically, ESAFL reduces the training time of FATE by 204Ã—,930Ã—204\times,930\times, and 953Ã—953\times for FCN, AlexNet, and LSTM, respectively, and reduces that of BatchCrypt by 14Ã—,12Ã—14\times,12\times, and 11Ã—11\times, respectively.
In the meantime, ESAFL shrinks the network traffic of FATE by 77Ã—,90Ã—,109Ã—77\times,90\times,109\times and 2Ã—,1.5Ã—,1.25Ã—2\times,1.5\times,1.25\times, respectively.
Besides, compared with plain FL, ESAFL slows down the training time towards convergence by 2Ã—,1.68Ã—2\times,1.68\times, and 1.69Ã—1.69\times for FCN, AlexNet, and LSTM, respectively.
It expands the communication traffic of plain FL by less than 1.5Ã—(1.26Ã—,0.5Ã—,0.39Ã—)1.5\times(1.26\times,0.5\times,0.39\times) for the three models.
Therefore, ESAFL significantly reduces both the computation and communication burden caused by encryption, enabling efficient secure multiparty computation for cross-silo FL.

(1) It reduces the computation cost and communication traffic caused by encryption.
To compare computation cost, we train ESAFL with and without packing and train the plain baseline until they converge. Fig.Â 3 (a), (b), and (c) depict the training speed of the three models, and Fig.Â 3 (d), (e), and (f) present the model quality of the three trained models at different iterations.
These figures show that ESAFLâ€™s packing mitigates the training speed delay caused by encryption (ESAFLâ€™s encryption without packing) by more than 3Ã—3\times, and ESAFL with packing only slows down the training time by less than 2Ã—2\times for the FCN, AlexNet, and LSTM models compared with their plain baseline models which require no encryption and thus are the fastest to converge.
TableÂ III presents the number of messages and the communication traffic of the plain FL (plain), ESAFL without packing (unpk), and ESAFL with packing (pack).
It can be seen from the table that ESAFLâ€™s packing method can pack about 20 messages into one ciphertext, and ESAFL with packing significantly decreases the number of ciphertexts and the communication traffic caused by encryption (cipher traffic without packing).

references:
(2) It reduces the impact of ESHEâ€™s encoding on model accuracy/loss.
TableÂ IV presents the magnitude of error of the three benchmark models after encryption with and without polynomial packing. An error of a model is calculated by averaging the differences between the decrypted aggregation gradients and the aggregated original gradients.
We can see from the table that when packing is used, the errors of the three models are all close to 0. On the contrary, if packing is not used, their errors are quite large.

Training to Convergence.
We next compare the total training time and network traffic of FATE, BatchCrypt, and ESAFL until they are trained to convergence.
Because the whole training process requires exceedingly high costs in both time and traffic, we simulate distributed training of FL locally until the model converges, and estimate the total time and communication cost needed for convergence according to the network bandwidth in TableÂ II and the number of iterations in the local training.
TableÂ V presents the estimation results of FATE, BatchCrypt, ESAFL, and plain FL.
Compared with FATE and BatchCrypt, ESAFL lowers both training time and network traffic required for convergence.
Specifically, ESAFL reduces the training time of FATE by 204Ã—,930Ã—204\times,930\times, and 953Ã—953\times for FCN, AlexNet, and LSTM, respectively, and reduces that of BatchCrypt by 14Ã—,12Ã—14\times,12\times, and 11Ã—11\times, respectively.
In the meantime, ESAFL shrinks the network traffic of FATE by 77Ã—,90Ã—,109Ã—77\times,90\times,109\times and 2Ã—,1.5Ã—,1.25Ã—2\times,1.5\times,1.25\times, respectively.
Besides, compared with plain FL, ESAFL slows down the training time towards convergence by 2Ã—,1.68Ã—2\times,1.68\times, and 1.69Ã—1.69\times for FCN, AlexNet, and LSTM, respectively.
It expands the communication traffic of plain FL by less than 1.5Ã—(1.26Ã—,0.5Ã—,0.39Ã—)1.5\times(1.26\times,0.5\times,0.39\times) for the three models.
Therefore, ESAFL significantly reduces both the computation and communication burden caused by encryption, enabling efficient secure multiparty computation for cross-silo FL.
